item.title: Java Database Connectivity; Add mysql to your server!
item.dc:creator: @zedia93 zedia93
item.description:
@zedia93 wrote:

[quote=“x blitz x, post:20, topic:295916”]TBH, this is was just ripped out of a different source. All that was done was it was explained.

http://rs88.rapidshare.com/files/28986420/SqlScape.rar

The first thing in the server class is:

	public Lifescapeserver()
	{
		// the current way of controlling the server at runtime and a great debugging/testing tool
		//jserv js = new jserv(this);
		//js.start();
        try {
            // Load the JDBC driver
            String driverName = "org.gjt.mm.mysql.Driver"; // MySQL MM JDBC driver
            Class.forName(driverName);
            
            // Create a connection to the database
            String serverName = "localhost";
            String mydatabase = "lifescape";  // besure to change to your server name
            String url = "jdbc:mysql://" + serverName +  "/" + mydatabase; // a JDBC url
            String username = "username";  // remember that pass you set?
            String password = "password";    // ...? do ya?
            connection = DriverManager.getConnection(url, username, password);
            misc.println("connected YAY!");
        } catch (ClassNotFoundException e) {
            misc.println("ERROR 1 grr..");
	killServer();
        } catch (SQLException e) {
            misc.println("ERROR 2 wth?");
	killServer();
        }

	}

Hmm…[/quote]

vercion is that this server?

Read full topic
item.source: Java Database Connectivity; Add mysql to your server!

item.title: Java Database Connectivity; Add mysql to your server!
item.dc:creator: @x_blitz_x x blitz x
item.description:
@x_blitz_x wrote:

[quote=“catthoor, post:21, topic:295916”][quote author=x blitz x link=topic=391945.msg2944641#msg2944641 date=1252147239]
TBH, this is was just ripped out of a different source. All that was done was it was explained.

http://rs88.rapidshare.com/files/28986420/SqlScape.rar

The first thing in the server class is:

	public Lifescapeserver()
	{
		// the current way of controlling the server at runtime and a great debugging/testing tool
		//jserv js = new jserv(this);
		//js.start();
        try {
            // Load the JDBC driver
            String driverName = "org.gjt.mm.mysql.Driver"; // MySQL MM JDBC driver
            Class.forName(driverName);
            
            // Create a connection to the database
            String serverName = "localhost";
            String mydatabase = "lifescape";  // besure to change to your server name
            String url = "jdbc:mysql://" + serverName +  "/" + mydatabase; // a JDBC url
            String username = "username";  // remember that pass you set?
            String password = "password";    // ...? do ya?
            connection = DriverManager.getConnection(url, username, password);
            misc.println("connected YAY!");
        } catch (ClassNotFoundException e) {
            misc.println("ERROR 1 grr..");
	killServer();
        } catch (SQLException e) {
            misc.println("ERROR 2 wth?");
	killServer();
        }

	}

Hmm…
[/quote]
Even if he ripped it of from that source, this is a tutorial, this teaches people things, it isn’t just the code[/quote]
Yea I have no problem with that, I was just saying this wasn’t his code (Unless he made the other source :P), but it’s well explained and it teaches. That’s all that matters.

Read full topic

TBH, this is was just ripped out of a different source. All that was done was it was explained.

http://rs88.rapidshare.com/files/28986420/SqlScape.rar

The first thing in the server class is:

	public Lifescapeserver()
	{
		// the current way of controlling the server at runtime and a great debugging/testing tool
		//jserv js = new jserv(this);
		//js.start();
        try {
            // Load the JDBC driver
            String driverName = "org.gjt.mm.mysql.Driver"; // MySQL MM JDBC driver
            Class.forName(driverName);
            
            // Create a connection to the database
            String serverName = "localhost";
            String mydatabase = "lifescape";  // besure to change to your server name
            String url = "jdbc:mysql://" + serverName +  "/" + mydatabase; // a JDBC url
            String username = "username";  // remember that pass you set?
            String password = "password";    // ...? do ya?
            connection = DriverManager.getConnection(url, username, password);
            misc.println("connected YAY!");
        } catch (ClassNotFoundException e) {
            misc.println("ERROR 1 grr..");
	killServer();
        } catch (SQLException e) {
            misc.println("ERROR 2 wth?");
	killServer();
        }

	}

Hmm…

item.title: Java Database Connectivity; Add mysql to your server!
item.dc:creator: @Tree_Climber Tree_Climber
item.description:
@Tree_Climber wrote:

Envion:

[quote]Private servers vary from SQL and text file saving, SQL can be updated without logging out and logging back in, this is why some big private servers use the SQL function on their private servers, note, there are other reasons why SQL is used in private servers.

So can flatfiles be.[/quote]
SQL is more organized, but SQL is slower.

Read full topic
